Hi,
	suppose in a system you have more than one type of mutation.  They might 
differ in being inserts vs deletes, or you might even consider mutations at 
different locations to be different types.

	OK, now suppose that the population is in mid-evolve and I want to know 
the most constructive ratio of the different types of mutation to 
attempt.  How do the following grab you.

1) whenever a mutation happens, increment a counter corresponding to its 
type and also note on the new individual what type of mutation produced it
2) whenever an individual dies, decrement the counter corresponding to the 
mutation that produced it
3) allocate attempted mutations proportionally to the current state of the 
counters

	As ever, I also generated a few variations on the idea:

1a) not only store the latest mutations on an individual, but also store 
(and count) the total numbers of all mutations found in its ancestry (if 
you have sex then you either need to count correctly whether a mutation was 
preserved in the crossover, or else average the numbers from each 
parent).  Now you are counting not just the last generation of successful 
mutations but the whole history of successful mutations

1b) as 1a but just for the last N generations, not the whole of time

1c) rather than incrementing the counters immediately, do it only after the 
new individual passes some test (fitness, longevity, #offspring)

2a) rather than decrementing the counters when an individual dies, do it 
only when one dies too young (assuming you do not replace the whole 
population in every tick)

3a) allocate attempted mutations according to the counters but using some 
function "flatter" than the raw counters.  So that rarely successful 
mutations become less common, but not too uncommon

	thoughts anyone?

	Ian
